title: Acceleration profiles and processing methods for parabolic flight
background: Parabolic flights provide cost-effective access to weightless and reduced gravity conditions but lack standardized acceleration data and analysis methods. These flights simulate space environments for research validation but reference profiles are not widely available.
objective: To develop and validate an open-source solution for collecting, analyzing, and classifying altered gravity environments during parabolic flights, enabling better planning and analysis of space analog experiments.
methods: Used Slam Stick X™ accelerometer on Boeing 727-200F with 20 parabolas, implemented Euclidean norm for orientation-independent analysis, applied change point detection algorithms, and developed unsupervised classification of flight phases.
results: Achieved 0.041±0.005 g during 0g parabolas (19.5±1.4s duration), 0.159 g lunar gravity (23.7s), and 0.356 g Mars gravity (28.9±0.7s). Successfully classified all flight phases using change point detection and filtering methods.
conclusion: Provides comprehensive open-source tools for parabolic flight acceleration characterization, facilitating standardized experiment planning and analysis for space research validation.

learning_notes.note: The study achieved highly consistent reduced gravity levels across multiple parabolas: 0.041±0.005 g during 0g phases (17 parabolas, 19.5±1.4s duration), exactly 0.356 g for both Mars gravity parabolas (28.9±0.7s), and 0.159 g for lunar gravity (23.7s), demonstrating the precision achievable with modern parabolic flight operations.

The orientation-independent Euclidean norm approach (square root of x²+y²+z² acceleration components) enabled robust phase classification regardless of accelerometer mounting, crucial for experiments where optimal sensor orientation may conflict with other constraints. This method achieved <2% calibration error compared to Earth's 1g reference.

Two-stage change point detection successfully identified 48 mean g level transitions and 97 total flight periods automatically: first identifying mean changes, then applying linear slope detection within 10s windows to separate stable regimes from rapid transitions, achieving unsupervised classification of all flight phases.

The Slam Stick X™ hardware (65g, 76×30×15mm) provided advantages over NASA's SFEM including 10× lower mass/volume, wider temperature range (-40°C to +80°C), and dual DC/piezoelectric sensors enabling both g-level and high-frequency vibration measurement up to 20kHz, facilitating integration into diverse experimental payloads.

Filter optimization using power spectral density analysis determined 0.01 Hz as the optimal half-power frequency for zero-phase Butterworth filtering, preserving parabola dynamics while rejecting higher frequency noise. This filtering reduced lateral acceleration noise while maintaining accurate g-level transitions critical for experiment timing.

The complete open-source solution includes raw/calibrated data (Open Science Framework), analysis code (GitHub), and hardware specifications, addressing the critical gap in publicly available parabolic flight acceleration references and enabling standardized comparison across research institutions and space agencies.

The methodology successfully classified flight phases using simple thresholds: parabola (≤0.9g), hypergravity (>1.1g), and other (0.9-1.1g) with duration filtering (>100s for 'other'), demonstrating that complex machine learning isn't always necessary for reliable parabolic flight analysis when proper preprocessing is applied.
